column1: Coon Rapids is a city in Carroll and Guthrie counties in the U.S. state of Iowa. The population was 1

column1: The entrepreneurial tradition that marks Coon Rapids was expressed in the twentieth century by businesses that served the diverse agricultural economy of the area. These included major grain dealers who maintained elevators in town
column4: a creamery and related produce stations
column6: a stock yard and sale barn. Of particular important to the town's 20th century life was the emergence of the hybrid corn business.

column1: Industrial agriculture transformed the Midwest in the post WW II era. Economies of scale shifted centers of production
column3: the poultry business became concentrated in the southeastern United States
column5: corporate rather than individual farming operations became the norm. For Coon Rapids this had varied impacts. Garst and Thomas Seed had expanded into an international concern by the mid-1950s offering local employment opportunities . Garst and Thomas expanded physically

column7: converting them to laboratory and office space. The city's residential areas grew during the late twentieth century

column15: Coon Rapids played a role in promoting détente between the United States and the Soviet Union
column16: when area resident Roswell Garst hosted Soviet premier Nikita Khrushchev on his farm.

column14: a local musician has initiated a series of house concerts which are held in a variety of venues. City leaders and residents continue to work to improve the quality of life in the community with the expectation Coon Rapids will remain a viable rural Iowa town far into the future.

column2: Coon Rapids-Whiterock area was elected a "Great Place" of Iowa for its rich history and resources
column3: and creative future vision. The Great Places program
column4: launched by Governor Tom Vilsack and implemented by the Department of Cultural Affairs
column5: aimed to concentrate state agency resources on high-potential communities.The local Great Place committee represents an alliance between the nonprofit Whiterock Conservancy
column7: and the Coon Rapids Development Group. Whiterock Conservancy is an Iowan nonprofit organized in late 2004 to administer a 5

column10: and low-impact public use and education.The first three Iowa Great Places (Coon Rapids
column11: Clinton and Sioux City) were each awarded $1 million in seed money by the Iowa legislature. In September 2007
column12: Coon Rapids was also awarded a $1.7 million Vision Iowa grant.  The Coon Rapids Great Place Program combines natural resource restoration with trails
